summary: This is a transcript of a telephone conference before Judge Loretta A. Preska in the civil case Giuffre v. Maxwell, concerning the unsealing of documents related to discovery motions. The judge announces rulings on the unsealing of numerous documents, balancing the public's First Amendment right of access against privacy interests, particularly for nonparty Does, Ghislaine Maxwell, and Virginia Giuffre. The ruling orders the unsealing of many documents with specific redactions for medical information, names of nonparty Does (except Does 1, 2, and Alan Dershowitz), and details of Maxwell's private sexual relationships.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the civil case Giuffre v. Maxwell. The judge rules on her arguments against unsealing, including concerns about a fair trial and privacy regarding her deposition testimony about intimate relationships.

persons.name: Loretta A. Preska
persons.context: The judge presiding over the telephone conference, announcing rulings on the unsealing of documents in the Giuffre v. Maxwell case.

persons.name: Sigrid S. McCawley
persons.context: Attorney from Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP representing the plaintiff (Virginia Giuffre) in the case. She speaks during the conference regarding unsealing procedures.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon Morgan and Foreman, P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell. She argues for sealing certain documents and requests logistical accommodations.

persons.name: Virginia Giuffre
persons.context: Referred to as 'Giuffre' in the transcript. The judge notes her privacy interests in medical records and as a minor victim in police reports.

persons.name: Julie Brown
persons.context: A journalist with the Miami Herald who, along with her media company, intervened in the case regarding the unsealing of documents.

persons.name: Christine N. Walz
persons.context: Attorney from Holland & Knight representing intervenors Julie Brown and Miami Herald Media Company.

persons.name: Paul M. Krieger
persons.context: Attorney from Krieger Kim & Lewin, LLP representing John Doe defendants. He speaks briefly about the Court's obligation to consider non-objecting Does.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Harvard Law professor. The judge rules that his name and identifying information may be unsealed as he affirmatively requested the redactions of his name be lifted.

persons.name: Steven Olson
persons.context: Referred to as Dr. Steven Olson. His deposition excerpts are among the documents subject to unsealing rulings, with redactions for medical information.

persons.name: Robert Sweet
persons.context: Referred to as Judge Sweet, the judge who previously decided the discovery motions at issue in this unsealing process.

persons.name: Meredith Schultz
persons.context: An attorney involved in the case; correspondence between her and other lawyers is subject to unsealing rulings.

persons.name: Ty Gee
persons.context: An individual whose correspondence is among the documents ordered unsealed.

persons.name: Bernadette Martin
persons.context: An individual whose correspondence with Meredith Schultz is among the documents ordered unsealed.

persons.name: Joseph Recarey
persons.context: Referred to as Detective Recarey. The judge rules that material relating to him may be unsealed as he is a law enforcement official, not a Doe.

connections.description: Maxwell is the defendant and Giuffre is the plaintiff in the civil case Giuffre v. Maxwell, which involves allegations of sex trafficking and abuse.
McCawley is an attorney representing plaintiff Virginia Giuffre in the civil case.
Menninger is an attorney representing defendant Ghislaine Maxwell in the civil case.
Walz is an attorney representing intervenor Julie Brown and the Miami Herald Media Company in the unsealing matter.
Dershowitz is a nonparty in the case who requested his name be unsealed in documents related to the Maxwell case.
Judge Sweet previously presided over and decided the discovery motions that are the subject of the current unsealing proceedings.

events.title: Telephone Conference on Document Unsealing
events.description: Judge Loretta A. Preska holds a telephone conference to announce rulings on the unsealing of documents associated with specific docket entries in Giuffre v. Maxwell.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell's Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell gave a deposition in July 2016 where she was asked about her sexual activity with consenting adults. The judge rules portions detailing her private intimate relationships should remain sealed.

events.title: Order to Unseal Documents with Redactions
events.description: Judge Preska orders the unsealing of 156 documents with specific redactions for medical information, names of nonparty Does (except Does 1, 2, and Alan Dershowitz), and private details from Maxwell's deposition.

events.title: Unauthorized YouTube Broadcast
events.description: During the conference, the deputy clerk informs the judge that someone is illegally broadcasting the proceeding on YouTube. The judge admonishes the broadcaster.

keyFacts: Judge Preska orders the unsealing of numerous documents from the Giuffre v. Maxwell case but mandates redactions to protect medical information, names of most nonparty Does, and details of Ghislaine Maxwell's private sexual relationships with consenting adults.
The names and identifying information for 'Does 1 and 2' and Alan Dershowitz are ordered to be unsealed. Dershowitz affirmatively requested the release of his name.

The judge rejects Ghislaine Maxwell's argument that unsealing documents would jeopardize her right to a fair trial in her pending criminal case, finding it insufficient to overcome the public's First Amendment right of access.

Portions of Ghislaine Maxwell's July 2016 deposition testimony regarding her intimate relationships with consenting adults are ordered to remain sealed to protect her privacy, as they are deemed far afield from the core sex trafficking allegations.

Police reports obtained through public records requests are to be unsealed in the form they were received from law enforcement agencies, with redactions for addresses and personal information of minor victims.
